Tom Warren of The Verge said that although Windows 8's emphasis on touch computing was significant and risked alienating desktop users, a "tablet PC with Windows 8 makes an iPad feel immediately out of date" due to the capabilities of the operating system's hybrid model and increased focus on cloud services. In biology, energy is an attribute of all biological systems from the biosphere to the smallest living organism. Within an organism it is responsible for growth and development of a biological cell or an organelle of a biological organism. Energy is thus often said to be stored by cells in the structures of molecules of substances such as carbohydrates (including sugars), lipids, and proteins, which release energy when reacted with oxygen in respiration. In human terms, the human equivalent (H-e) (Human energy conversion) indicates, for a given amount of energy expenditure, the relative quantity of energy needed for human metabolism, assuming an average human energy expenditure of 12,500 kJ per day and a basal metabolic rate of 80 watts. For example, if our bodies run (on average) at 80 watts, then a light bulb running at 100 watts is running at 1.25 human equivalents (100 ÷ 80) i.e. 1.25 H-e. From 1877 to 1878, the area suffered a rash of stagecoach robberies. Most notable, however, were the two holdups committed by masked road-agent William Whitney Brazelton. Brazelton held up two stages in the summer of 1878 near Point of Mountain Station approximately 17 mi (27 km) northwest of Tucson. John Clum, of Tombstone, Arizona fame was one of the passengers. Brazelton was eventually tracked down and killed on Monday August 19, 1878, in a mesquite bosque along the Santa Cruz River 3 miles (5 km) south of Tucson by Pima County Sheriff Charles A. Shibell and his citizen's posse. Brazelton had been suspected of highway robbery not only in the Tucson area, but also in the Prescott region and Silver City, New Mexico area as well. In 633 AD, Rashidun Arabs invaded Iran and conquered it by 651 AD, largely converting Iranian people from their indigenous faiths of Manichaeism and Zoroastrianism to Sunni Islam. Arabic replaced Persian as the official language, while Persian remained the language of both ordinary people and of literature. Iran became a major contributor to the Islamic Golden Age, producing many influential scientists, scholars, artists, and thinkers. Establishment of the Safavid Dynasty in 1501, converted the Iranian people from Sunni Islam to Twelver Shia Islam, and made Twelver Shia Islam the official religion of Iran. Safavid conversion of Iran from Sunnism to Shiism marked one of the most important turning points in Iranian and Muslim history. Starting in 1736 under Nader Shah, Iran reached its greatest territorial extent since the Sassanid Empire, briefly possessing what was arguably the most powerful empire

Carolingian art was produced for a small group of figures around the court, and the monasteries and churches they supported. It was dominated by efforts to regain the dignity and classicism of imperial Roman and Byzantine art, but was also influenced by the Insular art of the British Isles. Insular art integrated the energy of Irish Celtic and Anglo-Saxon Germanic styles of ornament with Mediterranean forms such as the book, and established many characteristics of art for the rest of the medieval period. Surviving religious works from the Early Middle Ages are mostly illuminated manuscripts and carved ivories, originally made for metalwork that has since been melted down. Objects in precious metals were the most prestigious form of art, but almost all are lost except for a few crosses such as the Cross of Lothair, several reliquaries, and finds such as the Anglo-Saxon burial at Sutton Hoo and the hoards of Gourdon

The brief peace in Europe allowed Napoleon to focus on the French colonies abroad. Saint-Domingue had managed to acquire a high level of political autonomy during the Revolutionary Wars, with Toussaint Louverture installing himself as de facto dictator by 1801. Napoleon saw his chance to recuperate the formerly wealthy colony when he signed the Treaty of Amiens. During the Revolution, the National Convention voted to abolish slavery in February 1794. Under the terms of Amiens, however, Napoleon agreed to appease British demands by not abolishing slavery in any colonies where the 1794 decree had never been implemented. The resulting Law of 20 May never applied to colonies like Guadeloupe or Guyane, even though rogue generals and other officials used the pretext of peace as an opportunity to reinstate slavery in some of these places. The Law of 20 May officially restored the slave trade to the Caribbean colonies, not slavery itself.

Concerns were raised that secure boot could prevent or hinder the use of alternate operating systems such as Linux. In a post discussing secure boot on the Building Windows 8 blog, Microsoft developer Tony Mangefeste indicated that vendors would provide means to customize secure boot, stating that "At the end of the day, the customer is in control of their PC. Microsoft's philosophy is to provide customers with the best experience first, and allow them to make decisions themselves." Microsoft's certification guidelines for Windows 8 ultimately revealed that vendors would be required to provide means for users to re-configure or disable secure boot in their device's UEFI firmware. The works of Virgil almost from the moment of their publication revolutionized Latin poetry. The Eclogues, Georgics, and above all the Aeneid became standard texts in school curricula with which all educated Romans were familiar. Poets following Virgil often refer intertextually to his works to generate meaning in their own poetry. The Augustan poet Ovid parodies the opening lines of the Aeneid in Amores 1.1.1–2, and his summary of the Aeneas story in Book 14 of the Metamorphoses, the so-called "mini-Aeneid", has been viewed as a particularly important example of post-Virgilian response to the epic genre. Lucan's epic, the Bellum Civile has been considered an anti-Virgilian epic, disposing with the divine mechanism, treating historical events, and diverging drastically from Virgilian epic practice. The Flavian poet Statius in his 12-book epic Thebaid engages closely with the poetry of Virgil; in his epilogue he advises his poem not to "rival the divine Aeneid, but follow afar and ever venerate its footsteps."

In 1737, the Marathas defeated a Mughal army in their capital, Delhi itself in Battle of Delhi (1737). The Marathas continued their military campaigns against Mughals, Nizam, Nawab of Bengal and Durrani Empire to further extend their boundaries. They would start with annual raids, followed by collecting ransom from villages and towns while the declining Mughal Empire retained nominal control and finally taking over the region. He explained it with the example of Malwa region. Marathas built an efficient system of public administration known for its attention to detail. It succeeded in raising revenue in districts that recovered from years of raids, up to levels previously enjoyed by the Mughals. Throughout the history of the South Slavs, the vernacular, literary, and written languages (e.g. Chakavian, Kajkavian, Shtokavian) of the various regions and ethnicities developed and diverged independently. Prior to the 19th century, they were collectively called "Illyric", "Slavic", "Slavonian", "Bosnian", "Dalmatian", "Serbian" or "Croatian". As such, the term Serbo-Croatian was first used by Jacob Grimm in 1824, popularized by the Vienna philologist Jernej Kopitar in the following decades, and accepted by Croatian Zagreb grammarians in 1854 and 1859. At that time, Serb and Croat lands were still part of the Ottoman and Austrian Empires. Officially, the language was called variously Serbo-Croat, Croato-Serbian, Serbian and Croatian, Croatian and Serbian, Serbian or Croatian, Croatian or Serbian. Unofficially, Serbs and Croats typically called the language "Serbian" or "Croatian", respectively, without implying a distinction between the two, and again in independent Bosnia and Herzegovina, "Bosnian", "Croatian", and "Serbian" were considered to be three names of

In the months after the Shenyang conference Peng Dehuai went to Beijing several times to brief Mao and Zhou about the heavy casualties suffered by Chinese troops and the increasing difficulty of keeping the front lines supplied with basic necessities. Peng was convinced that the war would be protracted, and that neither side would be able to achieve victory in the near future. On 24 February 1952, the Military Commission, presided over by Zhou, discussed the PVA's logistical problems with members of various government agencies involved in the war effort. After the government representatives emphasized their inability to meet the demands of the war, Peng, in an angry outburst, shouted: "You have this and that problem... You should go to the front and see with your own eyes what food and clothing the soldiers have! Not to speak of the casualties! For what are they giving their lives? We have no aircraft. We have only a few guns. Transports are not protected. More and more soldiers are dying of starvation.

By 1959, American observers believed that the Soviet Union would be the first to get a human into space, because of the time needed to prepare for Mercury's first launch. On April 12, 1961, the USSR surprised the world again by launching Yuri Gagarin into a single orbit around the Earth in a craft they called Vostok 1. They dubbed Gagarin the first cosmonaut, roughly translated from Russian and Greek as "sailor of the universe". Although he had the ability to take over manual control of his spacecraft in an emergency by opening an envelope he had in the cabin that contained a code that could be typed into the computer, it was flown in an automatic mode as a precaution; medical science at that time did not know what would happen to a human in the weightlessness of space. Vostok 1 orbited the Earth for 108 minutes and made its reentry over the Soviet Union, with Gagarin ejecting from the spacecraft at 7,000 meters (23,000 ft), and landing

The island of Saint Helena has a total area of 122 km2 (47 sq mi), and is composed largely of rugged terrain of volcanic origin (the last volcanic eruptions occurred about 7 million years ago). Coastal areas are covered in volcanic rock and warmer and drier than the centre. The highest point of the island is Diana's Peak at 818 m (2,684 ft). In 1996 it became the island's first national park. Much of the island is covered by New Zealand flax, a legacy of former industry, but there are some original trees augmented by plantations, including those of the Millennium Forest project which was established in 2002 to replant part of the lost Great Wood and is now managed by the Saint Helena National Trust. On 1 September 1870, the battle opened with the Army of Châlons, with 202 infantry battalions, 80 cavalry squadrons and 564 guns, attacking the surrounding Prussian Third and Meuse Armies totaling 222 infantry battalions, 186 cavalry squadrons and 774 guns. General De Wimpffen, the commander of the French V Corps in reserve, hoped to launch a combined infantry and cavalry attack against the Prussian XI Corps. But by 11:00, Prussian artillery took a toll on the French while more Prussian troops arrived on the battlefield. The French cavalry, commanded by General Marguerite, launched three desperate attacks on the nearby village of Floing where the Prussian XI Corps was concentrated. Marguerite was killed leading the very first charge and the two additional charges led to nothing but heavy losses. The Canadian football field is 150 yards (137 m) long and 65 yards (59 m) wide with end zones 20 yards (18 m) deep, and goal lines 110 yards (101 m) apart. At each goal line is a set of 40-foot-high (12 m) goalposts, which consist of two uprights joined by an 18 1⁄2-foot-long (5.6 m) crossbar which is 10 feet (3 m) above the goal line. The goalposts may be H-shaped (both posts fixed in the ground) although in the higher-calibre competitions the tuning-fork design (supported by a single curved post behind the goal line, so that each post starts 10 feet (3 m) above the ground) is preferred. In 1939, the Bureau began compiling a custodial detention list with the names of those who would be taken into custody in the event of war with Axis nations. The majority of the names on the list belonged to Issei community leaders, as the FBI investigation built on an existing Naval Intelligence index that had focused on Japanese Americans in Hawaii and the West Coast, but many German and Italian nationals also found their way onto the secret list. Robert Shivers, head of the Honolulu office, obtained permission from Hoover to start detaining those on the list on December 7, 1941, while bombs were still falling over Pearl Harbor. Mass arrests and searches of homes (in most cases conducted without warrants) began a few hours after the attack, and over the next several weeks more than 5,500 Issei men were taken into FBI custody. The deliberate or accidental hybridising of two or more species of closely related animals through captive breeding is a human activity which has been in existence for millennia and has grown in recent times for economic purposes. The number of successful interspecific mammalian hybrids is relatively small, although it has come to be known that there is a significant number of naturally occurring hybrids between forms or regional varieties of a single species.[citation needed] These may form zones of gradation known as clines. Indeed, the distinction between some hitherto distinct species can become clouded once it can be shown that they may not only breed but produce fertile offspring. Some hybrid animals exhibit greater strength and resilience than either parent. This is known as hybrid vigor. The existence of the mule (donkey sire; horse dam) being used widely as a hardy draught animal throughout ancient and modern history is testament to this. Other well known examples are the lion/tiger hybrid, the liger, which is by far the largest big cat and sometimes used in circuses; and

A number of novel ideas about religion developed with the Enlightenment, including Deism and talk of atheism. Deism, according to Thomas Paine, is the simple belief in God the Creator, with no reference to the Bible or any other miraculous source. Instead, the Deist relies solely on personal reason to guide his creed, which was eminently agreeable to many thinkers of the time. Atheism was much discussed, but there were few proponents. Wilson and Reill note that, "In fact, very few enlightened intellectuals, even when they were vocal critics of Christianity, were true atheists. Rather, they were critics of orthodox belief, wedded rather to skepticism, deism, vitalism, or perhaps pantheism." Some followed Pierre Bayle and argued that atheists could indeed be moral men. BYU has 21 NCAA varsity teams. Nineteen of these teams played mainly in the Mountain West Conference from its inception in 1999 until the school left that conference in 2011. Prior to that time BYU teams competed in the Western Athletic Conference. All teams are named the "Cougars", and Cosmo the Cougar has been the school's mascot since 1953. The school's fight song is the Cougar Fight Song. Because many of its players serve on full-time missions for two years (men when they're 18, women when 19), BYU athletes are often older on average than other schools' players. The NCAA allows students to serve missions for two years without subtracting that time from their eligibility period. This has caused minor controversy, but is largely recognized as not lending the school any significant advantage, since players receive no athletic and little physical training during their missions. Of major Canadian cities, St. John's is the foggiest (124 days), windiest (24.3 km/h (15.1 mph) average speed), and cloudiest (1,497 hours of sunshine). St. John's experiences milder temperatures during the winter season in comparison to other Canadian cities, and has the mildest winter for any Canadian city outside of British Columbia. Precipitation is frequent and often heavy, falling year round. On average, summer is the driest season, with only occasional thunderstorm activity, and the wettest months are from October to January, with December the wettest single month, with nearly 165 millimetres of precipitation on average. This winter precipitation maximum is quite unusual for humid continental climates, which most commonly have a late spring or early summer precipitation maximum (for example, most of the Midwestern U.S.). The success of its football team made Notre Dame a household name. The success of Note Dame reflected rising status of Irish Americans and Catholics in the 1920s. Catholics rallied up around the team and listen to the games on the radio, especially when it knocked off the schools that symbolized the Protestant establishment in America — Harvard, Yale, Princeton, and Army. Yet this role as high-profile flagship institution of Catholicism made it an easy target of anti-Catholicism. The most remarkable episode of violence was the clash between Notre Dame students and the Ku Klux Klan in 1924. Nativism and anti-Catholicism, especially when directed towards immigrants, were cornerstones of the KKK's rhetoric, and Notre Dame was seen as a symbol of the threat posed by the Catholic Church. The Klan decided to have a week-long Klavern in South Bend. Switzerland lies between latitudes 45° and 48° N, and longitudes 5° and 11° E. It contains three basic topographical areas: the Swiss Alps to the south, the Swiss Plateau or Central Plateau, and the Jura mountains on the west. The Alps are a high mountain range running across the central-south of the country, comprising about 60% of the country's total area. The majority of the Swiss population live in the Swiss Plateau. Among the high valleys of the Swiss Alps many glaciers are found, totalling an area of 1,063 square kilometres (410 sq mi). From these originate the headwaters of several major rivers, such as the Rhine, Inn, Ticino and Rhône, which flow in the four cardinal directions into the whole of Europe. Boston has a continental climate with some maritime influence, and using the −3 °C (27 °F) coldest month (January) isotherm, the city lies within the transition zone from a humid subtropical climate (Köppen Cfa) to a humid continental climate (Köppen Dfa), although the suburbs north and west of the city are significantly colder in winter and solidly fall under the latter categorization; the city lies at the transition between USDA plant hardiness zones 6b (most of the city) and 7a (Downtown, South Boston, and East Boston neighborhoods). Summers are typically warm to hot, rainy, and humid, while winters oscillate between periods of cold rain and snow, with cold temperatures. As Muslim institutions of higher learning, the madrasa had the legal designation of waqf. In central and eastern Islamic lands, the view that the madrasa, as a charitable endowment, will remain under the control of the donor (and their descendent), resulted in a "spurt" of establishment of madaris in the 11th and 12th centuries. However, in Western Islamic lands, where the Maliki views prohibited donors from controlling their endowment, madaris were not as popular. Unlike the corporate designation of Western institutions of higher learning, the waqf designation seemed to have led to the exclusion of non-orthodox religious subjects such a philosophy and natural science from the curricula. The madrasa of al-Qarawīyīn, one of the two surviving madaris that predate the founding of the earliest medieval universities and are thus claimed to be the "first universities" by some authors, has acquired official university status as late as 1947. In 1954, major Serbian and Croatian writers, linguists and literary critics, backed by Matica srpska and Matica hrvatska, began to gather from all over Slavic countries to form the League of Writers from Yugoslavia. The project's initiators were Ivan Golac and Vjekoslav Kovačić.

The League began by gathering Serbian and Croatian writers in Belgrade to promote Serbian language and literature. Then the writers gathered in Zagreb in 1960, where the second meeting of the League was held. In August 1961, the third meeting of the Writers' League was held, at which the project of a Serbian journal, "Dalmatinska jezera", was founded. The journal, directed by Milivoje Župančić, is still being published today.

The Bush administration then turned its attention to Iraq, and argued the need to remove Saddam Hussein from power in Iraq had become urgent. Among the stated reasons was that a democratic Iraq would be unable to defend itself against Saddam's WMD. Bush, however, argued it was less important for the US to remove Hussein from power in Iraq than for the US to prevent the spread of its Islamist and anti-Western ideology. Therefore, it was crucial that Hussein's political rivals in Iraq be removed.

An adolescent's environment plays a huge role in their identity development. While most adolescent studies are conducted on white, middle class children, studies show that the quality of social resources adolescents receive from their families is a stronger and more lasting factor than family income. For example, research by Adeyemo and colleagues has shown that poverty in adolescence is an important factor in adolescent drug use. More recently, Adeyemo (2005) demonstrated that adolescents from lower socioeconomic backgrounds are more likely to become chronic drug users than adolescents from higher socioeconomic backgrounds, while providing other family-based variables such as family composition, stability, and emotional support did not protect from drug use for lower socioeconomic groups of adolescents. These findings are consistent with the Adeyemo study (2005) where the researchers showed that poverty among youth is positively related to the severity of drug problems, as well as other forms of substance use. As a result of these studies, it is clear that poverty is a significant factor in adolescents' substance use.

In the 15th century the dome was added and the naves extended back of the choir, uniting the building to the tower and forming a main transept. The main features of this expansion are the west gallery, surmounted by a Gothic rood screen, and the transepts with their two large arches with elaborate niches; these are the only surviving sections of the original complex. These features were demolished at the re-organisation of the church and in the late 19th century a new narthex was built. The old transepts have been rebuilt and a new south aisle added, which was a major restoration work with the assistance of the architect Sir William Chambers (1793–1865).

From the 1970s onward, Stuart Hall's pioneering work, along with that of his colleagues Paul Willis, Dick Hebdige, Tony Jefferson, and others, would be focused on the development of the term “dance culture.” Hall wrote, “We shall soon come to consider, along with many other things, dances—the most significant form of popular music, literature and art.” Hall believed that dance, and the culture surrounding dance, was an important part of the development of a nation. Mammalian hair, also known as pelage, can vary in color between populations, organisms within a population, and even on the individual organism. In a wide variety of species, including humans, the two primary forms of skin are the hairless and the hairy skins. The skin is composed of several layers: 1) the outermost layer is the stratum corneum which provides the barrier of the epidermis; 2) the outermost layer contains hair follicles which are composed of a hair shaft and three surrounding layers. The hair shaft contains the anlagen of the hair follicles; and 3) the innermost layer is the dermis, the fibrous septae, and the blood vessels. The dermis contains the sebaceous gland(s), glands of Langerhans, a lymphatic drainage system, and nerves. Jeffrey Long and Rick Kittles give a long critique of the application of FST to human populations in their 2003 paper "Human Genetic Diversity and the Recent Genetic Breakthrough" for the Proceedings of the Genetic Society of America.

Their conclusions were not as pessimistic as those put forward in the press -- they concluded that the break through could not be due just to the relatively simple process of population subdivision, but also that it involved significant evolutionary change.

The problem with their argument is that if it was an evolutionary process, it was a very rare one, and it wasn't in a single population, but a series of them. Hegel certainly intends to preserve what he takes to be true of German idealism, in particular Kant's insistence that ethical reason can and does go beyond the individual conscience. In arguing that idealism is a form of rationalism he would no doubt agree with Kant that a rationalism which did not privilege the ego's individual self-determination would have little attraction for Hegel so long as individual self-determination is still the moral and political ideal.

However, this will not be possible without the idea of an "ethics of the individual," whose ideal is not that of a person but of an individual, or a collectivity. The "ethics of the individual," Hegel insists, is a _mimēsis_. Israelites enjoyed political independence twice in ancient history, first during the periods of the Biblical judges followed by the United Monarchy.[disputed – discuss] On the contrary, Israel's political freedom was constantly threatened during the period of the Babylonian Exile.[disputed – discuss]

The Jewish people experienced two periods of independence during the Old Testament era. The first lasted approximately 1,800-1,400 BC, from the Babylonian Exile, until the construction of the Temple in Jerusalem during the Jewish War. The second lasted approximately 500-0 BC, from the Babylonian Exile after the capture of Jerusalem until the destruction of the Second Temple by Nebuchadnezzar at the end of the Second Temple Period. This period of independence was characterized by continuous attacks from surrounding nations, including nations that had converted to Judaism, by a strong military administration, and by strict Jewish laws.

In southeast Europe agrarian societies first appeared in the 7th millennium BC, attested by one of the earliest farming sites of Europe, discovered in the Tanais region in Hungary. By the 6th millennium BC, farming had been practiced elsewhere in the Near East, South Asia and Europe. There is no evidence for the evolution of these cultural practices from Bronze Age agricultural practices in the Near East; rather, farming developed independently at each of these sites ([@b1-ajas-18-0415]). Subsequently it was practiced in both the Near East and Europe under the influence of the early Neolithic expansion of the eastern Mediterranean into the Eurasian steppe. The timing and reasons for this expansion are still debated, with some arguing that it was related to the expansion of the major farming culture in the North Hemisphere ([@b2-ajas-18-0415]) -- however there is no clear pattern in which the sites are arranged on the evolutionary (cultural) timeline.

Knowledge, for Popper, was objective, both in the sense that it is objectively true (or truthlike), and also in the sense that it is a belief, a judgement, that is justified by an argument.

The philosopher, in his analysis of the concept of knowledge, saw truth and knowledge as belonging to a single realm, but that this was, and no doubt should be, a peculiar realm, since knowledge is, to put it bluntly, very much an area of activity. In the beginning of the twentieth century, Popper wrote that knowledge is nothing but "a generalization of an empirical phenomenon which has not been directly perceived by the person who has the knowledge, and has not been subject to experimental manipulation" (Popper, 1954[1946]: 16). Yet, since many have tried such manipulations over the years, including Popper, we know how wrong these first claims really are.

Strict separation of powers did not operate in The United Kingdom, the political structure of which served in most instances[citation needed] as a model for the system of separation of powers, at least not when such structure did not actually exist. Indeed, there is very little in the legal history of the British Parliament to indicate that Parliament had the authority so far to make the decisions that it did to govern the country. This, in any case, was part of the problem.

So, we now have a United Kingdom that has been subject to a form of government whose constitutional structure has never been formally defined by any constitution. It is now time to explore the relationship between the formal law of the Parliament under the authority of the British constitution and the people of the United Kingdom, in our current context as citizens.

They ran into difficulties when attempting to acquire more territories than a single king could claim. To circumvent this problem, Philip V of France was granted the Duchy of Burgundy by the emperor Charles VII in 1404. The Duchy came into his possession the following year. Though the Duchy was considered a small territory for his personal purposes, it provided Philip (and his successors) with important advantages and a powerful symbol of royal power.

The Jurassic Period extends from about 201.3 ± 0.2 to 145.0 Ma. During the early Jurassic, the supercontinent Pangaea broke down into individual segments, which eventually collided and coalesced to form the continent of North America. In this period marine ecosystems underwent considerable innovation. A transition between the two main clades of Paleozoic marine life (Cambrian and Silurian), which dominated the oceans until their extinction about 580 Ma, is the most significant innovation during this time. The Cambrian explosion, in which the rate of occurrence of the largest and most varied groups of eukaryota (including some of the most distinctive and beautiful organisms such as diatoms, stromatolitids, diatoms and sponges) has increased almost sixfold, is the single most important element of the transition from the Cambrian to the Jurassic.

Birds have a very efficient system for diffusing oxygen into the blood; birds have a ten times greater surface area to gas exchange volume than mammals. Birds breathe in air at a slightly negative pressure, which results in a low Reynolds number, and so they have aerodynamic drag. As a result, birds usually need to move upwards against the drag force. For long flights, they need to keep up with the wind and increase their height, until the air flowing over their wings forces them upward as well. Once they have gained enough altitude, the birds can drop down under the force of gravity once again. This descent, however, is an extremely difficult task, especially for flightless birds.

Birds glide, but there are few reasons to glide when flying. Birds mostly climb, but need to control their speed against the wind. One way to overcome these difficulties is to use the lift available in the air: the lift available in the air is about three times larger than the drag. Some

Identity development is a stage in the adolescent life cycle. For most, the search for identity begins in the adolescent years. During these years, adolescents explore and develop their identity as part of the developing self-concept ([@bibr12-2333721420921213]).

Many adolescents feel the pressure of fitting in with the group to find acceptance and to feel valued and wanted. In addition, adolescents seek to establish an identity for themselves and feel a sense of belonging that differs from the identity or views of the parent. Thus, self-esteem and self-concept are developed through social, interpersonal, organizational, and familial interactions. These relationships form the foundation of the adolescent's identity and set the stage for learning and development ([@bibr29-2333721420921213]).

Egocentrism in adolescents forms a self-conscious desire to feel important in their peer groups and enjoy social acceptance. Unlike the conflicting aspects of a romantic relationship, egocentrism is a stable and unchanging characteristic of adolescence. It is not an "acquired" characteristic, but one which naturally develops early in development. Adolescents who are egocentrically involved are always aware of their own interests and value. This will eventually lead to their "own" satisfaction even if they engage in the activity alone. Adolescents also tend to idealize themselves and feel that their relationships are worthwhile and therefore do not involve a loss of identity. This will lead to romantic relationships lasting a long time. (Charmaz 1999, p. 10) This statement by Charmaz does not imply that all adolescents are egocentric. Y DNA studies tend to imply a small number of founders in an old population whose members parted and followed different migration paths. In most Jewish populations, these founder individuals probably represent at most very few individuals within the total founding population, which itself might be quite large. It is not the case that in all groups the entire founder population must have departed from the ancestral population, but rather that the founding population was composed of a few founders who, in the majority of cases, left and migrated across larger geographic areas (or continents).

The deeper ancestral demography of Bermuda's population has been obscured by the ethnic homogenisation of the last four centuries. There is effectively no ethnic distinction between the two cities of St. George's (formerly the 'town' of St. George) and the historic capital of Hamilton.

On its arrival in 1788 its first European settlers were in fact mostly from English and Irish families, which brought English, Scottish and American with them. However, within 50 years a substantial Irish majority settled in Hamilton and the population remained relatively fixed at around 150–160 people throughout its time of independence (except in the aftermath of Hurricane Ivan), at a time when the number of Africans was around six per cent.

The body’s capability to react to antigen depends on a person's age, antigen type, maternal factors and the area where the antigen is presented.

A study by Dr Peter Gajewski and Dr John O’Connell of St Vincent’s Hospital, part of The University of Melbourne looked at how children react to cowpox, one of the most common childhood infectious diseases.

The researchers recruited 70 healthy children aged 10-12 years old. From their case notes, the researchers were able to determine that each child had a different antigen that they had been exposed to in the past 48 hours. Each child was then grouped according to its antigen as a baby group (grouped with their mothers or sisters that the children had been in contact with previously), an adult group (the child’s own mother, father or brothers) and a child at-risk group (the child’s mother or father who had not been previously in contact with their children).

Like the reptiles, birds are primarily uricotelic, that is, their kidneys extract nitrogenous waste from their bloodstream and excrete it as urine. This means that they can survive longer on protein than mammals.

But not every bird can live this way. There’s a bird on record called the vulturine. This was what you could call a manatee. It is the largest swimming marsupial and it had a body bigger than a whale, weighing in at over a ton.

There’s a second kind of uricotelic bird known as plovers. This comes right from the plumbobbers and it, too, is an animal that can get all its nitrogen from protein. Both birds have long legs that give them power and that’s why they can plumb across the oceans, diving to the depths to pull up all that protein.

Public priests were appointed by the collegia. Once elected, a priest held permanent religious authority from the eternal divine, which offered him lifetime influence, privilege, and power. He held the position of "priest" or diocesan "bishop," a position that was unique—the only one created during the Roman Empire. For example, a single priest may hold two different titular bishoprics (one for Latin and one for his native tongue, Greek); these are known as "dioceses." The dioceses were not independent, but were bound to the collegial system by the laws of a diocese.

In the early centuries of Christianity, the word "priest" or "bishop" also could be used to describe a member of a priesthood or episcopate. Anthropologists such as C. Loring Brace, the philosophers Jonathan Kaplan and Rasmus Winther, and the geneticist Joseph Graves,[page 1129] among others, have argued that most nonhuman animals are incapable of cultural learning. Cultural learning, also called "cultural evolution," is the basis of human cultures, or the nonhuman animals' cultural evolution. Cultural learning is how humans have created most of the cultural developments in the last 100,000 to 5,000 years on average.

What is required of these nonhuman animals is to learn the cultural repertoire or "rules of the game", and to learn that cultural development usually follows patterns rather than being randomly produced. Cultural evolution entails learning the cultural repertoire but without any memory of either the general structure of culture or of past patterns. (C. Many modern specialty matches have been devised, with unique winning conditions. The most common of these is the ladder match. In the basic ladder match, the first eight players in each block of twenty are paired up randomly in order of their respective points. To play, each player must match his points score with the score from his next opponent. The first person to match all twenty plus his opponent's points wins. There is no limit to the number of players in a single block, therefore a total of 400 players are matched in a single match.
The most exciting match in tennis is the final of the world's most famous amateur tournament, Wimbledon Championships. It is held each June for a two-week period. Sound could be stored in either analog or digital format and in a variety of surround sound formats; NTSC discs could carry two analog audio tracks, plus one digital audio track, while HD DVD used three analog audio tracks plus one digital audio track. Most DVDs had four audio tracks plus one or two digital audio tracks. Most Blu-ray Discs had six audio tracks plus one or two digital audio tracks.



Some surround sound formats offered the listener "virtual surround" modes in which left and right sound were combined using various techniques. From his diagrams of a small number of particles interacting in spacetime, Feynman could then model all of physics in terms of the spins of those particles and the relative angular momenta of their associated quanta. Feynman thought of a particle, but one with zero spin, spinless.

Feynman's diagrams do not represent the world we actually observe in terms of the world we find ourselves in.

In fact, if we consider photons interacting with the electron orbiting the proton in the nucleus of an atom, we can actually see two things that happen: Inelastic scattering off a photon by the electron changes the photon's momentum and thus changes its direction. If the photon then hits (and hence absorbs) a second electron, the second electron also moves. This creates a new photon--the electromagnetic version of the electron changing its energy into a different energy.

Although people often think that memory operates like recording equipment, it is not the case. The molecular mechanisms underlying the induction and maintenance of memory are very dynamic and, under certain circumstances, can be modified by experience. While a single experience can be the source of a permanent alteration of the molecular or cellular circuitry underlying memory formation and maintenance, recent evidence in animals has shown that several episodes of repeated learning or extinction can reverse this process (Schiller and Staehler, [@B26]). Memory therefore is not simply an instantaneous process. It is not a unitary or stable store of knowledge such as a photograph that can be recalled for every use; rather, it is a process that is dynamic and malleable. This article will discuss our current understanding of how the dynamic molecular changes that underlie long-term memory arise and how they might be regulated by experience.

A common way in which emotions are conceptualized in sociology is in terms of the multidimensional characteristics including cultural or emotional labels (e.g., \[[@pone.0142515.ref001]\]). Thus, the emotional state of others can be conceptualized as an affective label of others similar to one's own affective label. For example, someone who has an angry face that is similar in shape or form to the face of someone who is in an emotional state can say that the angry face is "his" angry face. This type of conceptualization can be useful in predicting someone's emotional state but may distort the complex relationships in a dyadic interaction, in which one person's emotional label also captures the emotional state of another person and vice versa.

Darwin was hard at work on his "big book" on Natural Selection, when on 18 June 1858 he received a parcel from Wallace, who was then completing his great book on the origin of species.

The letter from Wallace gave his new theory on the origin of species. Wallace's book, co-authored with Henslow, was published in three volumes in January 1859; Darwin received it as a gift and was only able to read three pages.

After Darwin read three pages of it, he put it down and never touched it; he decided he saw all he needed to see and that he could find all the answers to all his questions already in what Wallace had written.

It was then Darwin decided his "big work" would be a short volume dealing with the classification of the whole animal world, not only of its single parts, and he wrote a series of notes to it.

The two major types of nonprofit organization are membership and board-only. A membership organization elects the board and has regular meetings and the power to amend and revoke directors, but does not elect executive officers or have an annual budget. A board-only organization elects the directors on a permanent basis and has an annual budget; does not elect executives, as with a membership organization. However, since the number of boards and directors is small, the organizational emphasis is on the board, or in other words, executive control of the organization. With membership organizations, the focus is on the board. Members and board members must be treated the same, regardless of where they are in the organization.

When a baptized member is accused of committing a serious sin—usually cases of sexual misconduct or charges of apostasy—the church considers formal discipline when the accused is in danger of losing his or her salvation. The church also considers formal discipline when there has been a “rejection” of a member or when church discipline is needed to bring a member back into the church.

How are members disciplined?

Discipline is commonly, but not necessarily strictly, enforced. Elders have a wide amount of discretion as to whether to administer discipline. Church officials can decide to either wait until a member is no longer in danger of losing his or her salvation or to act immediately when it is clear that the person is in danger of losing his or her salvation.

What do the Church’s Discipline Rules say?

Following the Ulm Campaign, French forces managed to capture Vienna in November. The fall of Vienna provided the French a huge bounty as they captured 100,000 men, women, and children to replace the losses in the campaign, who had all been sold into slavery in the Ottoman Empire.

In terms of military personnel, France lost 1,100 officers and men during the campaign, including one-third of its naval corps. France lost 7,500 infantrymen and 8,000 cavalrymen out from its army in Italy, for a total of 25,600 servicemen in all. By war's end in 1799, France had taken a total of 10,744 soldiers from Italy, 4,749 of whom were taken prisoner at the end of the campaign.

After Napoleon invaded Italy, much of it came under French control; however, Austria retained the strategic position of southern Italy and was the main obstacle preventing France and Russia from attacking.

Since re-establishing independence, Estonia has styled itself as the gateway between East and West and aggressively pursued economic reform and integration with the West. Estonia has sought to be a major power in the post-Communist world by embracing its cultural and political heritage and its role in Europe and by working to meet its membership obligations on many economic fronts.

In the summer of 2008 Estonia successfully completed its accession process in preparation for joining a European Union (EU) common market and Euro currency. The political structure of Western Europe changed with the end of the united Roman Empire. Although the movements of peoples during this period are usually described as "invasions", these were in fact movements of armies of a number of peoples. During the first few centuries CE, the dominant peoples in Western Europe tended to be settled farmers, but with the end of the Roman Empire, political systems developed from above down. At first a military government was created: Rome was transformed into a political monarchy, its military became an administrative elite, and the emperor became a monarch. At this period, Roman institutions such as the senate, law courts, army, and bureaucracy were gradually replaced by those of the various nations in Western Europe, and gradually this process continued. As this process matured, each of the new monarchs needed a government body to direct and control its armies, courts of justice, administration, and legal policies. Comprehensive schools have been accused of grade inflation after a study revealed that Gymnasium senior students of average mathematical ability found themselves at the very bottom of mathematics in the most prestigious of secondary schools.

When the first comprehensive school with a university course offered by the state, the one at the University of Cambridge, was opened here in the 1990s, it caused uproar because of what some saw as under-representation of the socially disadvantaged.

Now new statistics suggest that, while at one stage in the early 2000s, the academically underperforming "A" band students of Cambridge, one of the most selective state schools, were at the highest end of the school grade system (i.e. first-year students were given a grade of 2 GCSEs or more), by 2012 they were at the bottom end in all exams. By contrast, the state-run comprehensive with the same university offered only 3 GCSEs would have awarded a grade of 16 GCSEs.

The university culture developed differently in northern Europe than it did in the south, although the northern (primarily Germany, France and Great Britain) and southern parts of the European continent had been exposed to a similar set of forces through Germanic expansion well before the industrial revolution. While southern European universities developed as part of the 'liberal', Europeanizing culture, the 'conservative' northern universities were far more influenced, even dominated by, their 'proletarian' intellectual milieu. This development differed considerably from the developments in Europe's capital cities, where new universities were established between 1850 and 1910, with the University of Berlin (founded by the Berlin University of Political Science in 1865) and Cambridge University (founded by the Cambridge University Philosophical Society in 1546) being the most notable.

The Yale Report of 1828 was a dogmatic defense of the Latin and Greek curriculum against critics who wanted more courses in modern languages, mathematics, and theology. For example, it defended the use of Latin as a foundation for classical studies. Students of the curriculum had reason to feel this was not the case.

But what was the Yale Report worth to the college? The Yale men charged with its making were not responsible to Yale, but to their own college. They were also charged with trying to bring about a national system of education, which was not yet a reality. Yale was in the same situation as schools that in the 1830s insisted on keeping the Bible in the classrooms, with no way of making it fit in with the curriculum.

The Yale-Princeton Report on the Latin and Greek Basis of Secondary Education (1828), by Yale College presidents Samuel P. Mills and William T. Thornton, became the model for the federal system of higher education.

Microbiological culture is a principal tool used to diagnose infectious disease. In a microbial culture, a growth medium is provided for a specific agent. A nutrient is added to the growth medium such as nutrients for bacterial culture. Thereafter, the particular nutrient added is replaced into the growth medium to cause the culturable bacteria present in the growth medium to grow and form colonies. Bacteria colonies present in the growth medium can be cultivated under aerobic or anaerobic conditions, and the growth of the colonies may or may not be affected by the nutrient added.
Among microbes to be measured in a bacterial culture are pathogenic microorganisms such as Legionella pneumophila, for determining the presence of Legionella pneumophila in a sample, or Mycobacterium chelonei, for determining the presence of Mycobacterium chelonei. The current Mac product family uses Intel x86-64 processors. Apple introduced an emulator during the transition from PowerPC chips (called Rosetta), much to the dismay of some developers, and an emulation layer for the Intel DTrace and Intel VTx instruction sets. The latter is a powerful extension of Intel’s hardware virtualization technology for Intel x86 CPUs that was designed to run an operating system, often named VMWare. It would run on top of a virtualized Intel x86-64 architecture and would be based on an x86-64 instruction set so that the virtual machine could run on top of it.

It’s possible to compile VMWare onto an Intel x86 processor running macOS, and run a VMWare-based operating system on top of macOS. There are many limitations, which we’ll discuss when we discuss the Intel x86-64 processor and the VM system in OS X 10.10 Mountain Lion and up.

While medieval pageants and festivals such as Corpus Christi were church-sanctioned, Carnival was also a manifestation of medieval folk culture. Many local communities and families, having lost a loved one in a war, would organise the carnival to raise money for the dead’s burial, or to help their neighbours or relatives after the departure of their lost loved one. Other local communities would organise a ‘Carnival of All Fares’ to honour their deceased loved one by giving a variety of cultural items such as food for eating and games. In many communities, these festivals had a carnival character where people dressed up, decorated their homes with special foods and crafts and would march through their village in a colourful procession to the Carnival. In the past, local Carnival customs and traditions were usually related to religious or social events, but in the modern times, some of these traditions have become associated with contemporary society. In 1969, Schwarzenegger met Barbara Outland (later Barbara Outland Baker), an English teacher he lived with until 1974. Schwarzenegger talked about Barbara in his 2004 autobiography, Born to Train. He said she saved him. When he was in a car collision, she got him out of the wreckage. He wrote that he could have not survived in the accident, but that since she held his head while pulling him out, she saved his life. She later married and had two children.

Barbara later became an American citizen, and the family moved to America. She is active in local Republican politics and is the former chair of the National Association of Realtors. She is a member of the board of directors of the University of Southern California's Annenberg School for Communication at Los Angeles. Also Barbara owns a restaurant in Hollywood called "Barbara's Beach House." In January 2012, Schwarzenegger and Inland's daughter Autumn opened a second restaurant "Barbara's Table", dedicated to Barbara.

Protestantism also spread from the German lands into France, where the Protestants were nicknamed Huguenots. Calvin continued to take an interest in French Huguenots, and sent many French converts back to the Calvinist side.  The English Protestants became known as Cavaliers.

In the mid-17th century, English Protestantism split between two tendencies, one being the radical and Calvinist tendency and another being the more moderate and conservative tendency. During the American Revolution, much of this split was reflected in the fact that the Puritan and Revolutionary movements were largely one, and that in some places they were almost identical.

In the 17th century, the English movement began to split into two more clearly distinct strands. Among the moderates in England, the Evangelical Anglican Church grew stronger; while among the radicals, the Lutheran Church grew strong. Adolescence marks a rapid change in one's role within a family. Young children tend to assert themselves forcefully, but are unable to demonstrate much influence over their parents' choice of discipline. However, in adulthood, young adults are most apt to make the decisions for themselves and exert little control over their behavior. This is especially apparent as they enter into adulthood and gain more independence, with younger adolescents often having less supervision of their own choices than older adolescents do. In this chapter we examine these processes, emphasizing parental reinforcement of child discipline practices, from adolescence to young adulthood, particularly the ways in which parental practices can lead children down the slippery slope to misbehavior that can be avoided or redirected.

The role of parental practices in shaping young adolescents' behavior from childhood through adolescence and into adulthood has been the subject of many studies. The late 1980s saw a series of liberalising economic reforms within Libya designed to cope with the decline in oil revenues. In May 1987, Gaddafi announced a 20-year plan (1986-2001) aimed at boosting industrialisation and upgrading the country’s infrastructure. In January 1988, oil production had risen rapidly to over 3 million barrels per day. During the first decade of the new era, Gaddafi and his ministers built an authoritarian regime under which, among other measures, they dismantled the old order in an attempt to make the population compliant with their rule.

The regime began by targeting and harassing the conservative and monarchist elites. The first phase of the regime’s war on the old order was marked by a number of crackdowns on the pro-communist and anarchist sections of the society, including the suppression of anarchist publishing houses and anti-imperialist publications. The regime’s strategy of controlling and regulating the old order was complemented by a wave of land reforms

Homer refers to the "Hellenes" (/ˈhɛliːnz/) as a relatively small tribe settled in Thessalic Lakedaimon, around 700 BC. Most Homeric epic, with the possible exception of The Odes, is the work of authors in Thessalian Greek; in particular, he speaks of their being called Achaeans, from a word meaning "shouters" or "yellers". After the Trojan War, a number of Greek cities in Thessaly were granted independence by the Roman Republic or became clients of Rome and thus became part of the empire (see: Thesprotia). The Greeks would begin to develop a new literature, the Iliad, and the Odyssey; the Homeric epics had also played an important role in the development of the Greek language.

The European concept of "race", along with many of the ideas now associated with the term, arose at the time of the scientific revolution, which introduced a new perspective on human and biological differences through advances in science and in the techniques of observation and measurement. In the context of these new insights, a person-thing dichotomy emerged as well as the idea of human or civilising "races" that was not confined to an exclusively biological perspective. It became apparent that people were not homogeneous entities but had to be divided into different kinds of people, with a spectrum ranging from people with the "highest social position" (or "civilising "races") to an "immoral" and "barbaric" people. Among these human races was an upper, middle, and lower social stratum of civilisation. The Space Race was a 20th-century competition between two Cold War rivals, the Soviet Union (USSR) and the United States (US), aimed at developing a space program that would surpass that of its rivals. It ended with a joint Soviet and US program—the two parties working in complete cooperative harmony. They each were able to achieve their goals at different, even though complementary, times, with NASA leading the way with the construction of the Space Shuttle and the final Apollo missions of the 1960s.

What were the defining aspects of the US space program in the 1960s? Was the space race real or a myth? In this book, Pulitzer Prize-winning astronaut Roberta Bondar offers historical context and personal reflections. Bondar begins by outlining the challenges and opportunities of the 1960s. Successful cultivation of cotton requires a long frost-free period, plenty of sunshine, and a moderate rainfall, usually from 600 to 1,200 mm.

### **How to Set it Up**

#### **Watering System**

The water is distributed by a water system consisting of shallow, deep, and shallow wells, a sluice, and a pump. Water is delivered to the plant by a network of pipes and drains, and is available from the crop cycle. Deep and shallow wells are used for cultivating cotton and cotton seeds, which requires a continuous supply of water during the entire life of the plant. The water required is typically 350 to 400 cubic meters per hectare. A deep well (1.5 m deep) is used only for cultivation of dry crops and dry soil. Mary's complete sinlessness and concomitant exemption from any taint from the first moment of her existence was a doctrine familiar to Greek theologians of the 5th century BCE—especially those of the 2nd century BCE and the 2nd century CE. According to this Greek theological tradition, Mary alone was free of the original sin caused by Adam's eating of the forbidden fruit in the garden of Eden. This allowed Mary's status as the Immaculata to be understood as an exceptional one, and the Blessed Mother to be "the most perfect of all beings" able to offer her Son the ultimate and complete forgiveness that was made possible for all humans through the Incarnation.[9]

This was an extraordinarily important point in Christian theology, and a theme woven into the theological justification of Mary's position as a single point of departure between humanity and Heaven. Through Mary, who became an instrument of salvation, Jesus had reconciled our fallen human nature with the Divine Nature.

In October 2014, the trial of six senior staff and journalists at The Sun newspaper began. All six were charged with conspiring to commit misconduct in a public office when the Sun published a photo of an injured boy allegedly caused by police violence. Two were cleared at the time, but later tried following evidence that raised serious questions for all six.

On 2 December, and again on 30 November, a jury at Westminster Sheriff Court cleared the newspaper of all charges, with no single member of the six-man jury believing guilt beyond reasonable doubt. The trial at Newcastle Crown Court of those four journalists and two former editors is still ongoing.

The allegations against those six senior journalists – Simon Dendam, Neil Clark-Thomas, Andrew Bridgen, Simon Cooper, Paul Dacre and Ian McLarty – were reported by the BBC on 12 September before The Sun’s editor, Rebekah Brooks’s father, contacted the police. We will take the French from behind and force the passage of a river. The army will occupy the enemy's territory in the rear and occupy a line of roads in front. The bridge will be taken; the roads closed and the men distributed along these routes.

Intel had tried unsuccessfully to push Apple to migrate the Macintosh platform to Intel chips. Apple concluded that Intel's CISC (Complex Instruction Set Computer) architecture would not fit well in a Macintosh environment and Apple would prefer a CISC architecture.

Intel's response to the Mac was to go back on its original CISC concept and create the Pentium processor from 1998 to 2001. Intel's Pentium processor used an ARM-like superscalar architecture to run a single program at the same time, but had a significantly smaller number of instructions relative to the Pentium 2 processor it replaced: two to twelve versus sixty to three hundred. Boundaries can be inclusive or exclusive depending on how they are perceived by other people. An exclusive boundary arises, for example, when a person adopts only those aspects of another's life style that he/she knows, or believes, are not compatible with his/her own. On the other hand, an inclusive boundary is established when everyone in a given group shares in, and promotes, the positive aspects of the group. The boundary can also be positive and negative depending on its context. If it is positive with no negative undertones, it is understood that certain rules, behaviors, and restrictions are permissible. However, if it is negative in its undertones, people know that certain rules, behaviors, and restrictions are wrong. While the boundaries of an exclusive, positive, and negative or inclusive, can be formed and maintained over time, exclusive and positive boundaries are usually imposed immediately upon entering into a social relationship, while exclusive and positive boundaries are usually only accepted and maintained at a group or unit level

To maintain a high constant body temperature is energy expensive – mammals therefore need a nutritious and plentiful diet. While the earliest mammals were probably predators, different species of mammals have developed into predators and scavengers, as well as omnivores and herbivores.

The earliest mammals were probably predatory animals that hunted other species from some form of ambush. The early mammals, such as the pinesap of Australia, were ambush predators, feeding on their prey from below. The largest carnivores were hyenas, who became more specialized as more of their hunting was directed toward larger prey.

The hunting and feeding methods of early mammals were more directed toward larger prey and this allowed them to develop very large teeth, which allowed them to obtain larger prey, and to better process food before consumption. For example, the earliest humans were scavenging mammals, and were probably able to process and ingest very large food items, including nuts.

To prevent the risk of out-of-phase supplies mixing, sections of line fed from different feeder stations must be kept strictly isolated. This is achieved by a number of means, each of which has disadvantages, as will be described below.
A first means is to supply only one line with power at one time. This requires a heavy supply overhead at each line, and in the event of a short outage, the supply is interrupted.
A second means is to supply only the line with power necessary for the required current. For a line with a capacity of 5MW, for example, a supply of 12KV is required. In a large wind farm of the order of 500MW, however, the power available from a feeder that has only 12 KV available to feed one line may still be insufficient to feed that line.

Dorgon's controversial July 1645 edict (the "haircutting order") forced adult Han Chinese men to shave the front of their heads and grow the hair there. The order had serious implications for religious practices as well as the freedom of religion. But the reasons for the order are less important than the consequences.

The edict was issued to eliminate the "two-horned race" of China and bring China closer to Western ideals. It was intended to inspire Chinese to adopt Western values: Christianity, republican government, education, and scientific learning. These ideals were to be embodied in the Chinese Empire—which was to be built from the ground up, according to what was learned, and expanded according to what was achieved.

The relationships adolescents have with their peers, family, and members of their social sphere play a vital role in the social development of an adolescent. As an adolescent moves through these stages in the life course it is necessary that adolescents are able to move through these social networks to meet new challenges in this stage of their lives. This will enable them to take on challenges and opportunities they may not have met otherwise to find out what they are like, and how to interact with the world of adults while at the same time being able to know what they are like in their own unique social space in relation to their peers, classmates and siblings. Therefore, exploring how we can understand, measure and ultimately influence the way adolescents move through these social networks is an important issue of social science today. Most fatty acids are non-essential, meaning the body can produce them as needed, generally from other fatty acids and always by expending energy to do so. In other words, fatty acids are not used directly to perform the function of the molecule – fatty-acid oxidation for instance – but rather for their role in energy production and storage. As a consequence of being non-essential, and of energy extraction from them by oxidation or through other physical processes, the fatty acids have the lowest number of atoms among all fats. Fatty acids can contain carbon, hydrogen, and, sometimes, even oxygen and sulphur atoms, and, at the extreme, long chains of fatty acids. In fact, there are around 2000 different naturally occurring fatty acids which are found naturally in many foods, fats, and oils, and in the body. A standard adult football match consists of two periods of 45 minutes each, known as halves. Each half runs continuously, meaning that the clock is not stopped at the end of any one period. In one period, the referee calls the starting and restart of each side at 11 o'clock. These two starts start each half-60 seconds apart, meaning half-time is a minute, 30 seconds, or three minutes. The period of each team and whether the match is 2-legged or 3-legged are also determined during the first half. In an FFA Cup match, the teams play a maximum of 90 minutes on each side.

Communication within peer groups allows adolescents to explore their feelings and identity as well as develop and evaluate their social skills. In 1681, in partial repayment of a debt, Charles II of England granted William Penn a charter for what would become the Pennsylvania colony. Despite the loss of the entire province following a series of rebellions, he continued to seek new lands. He traveled east in an attempt to create a colony on the coast of Asia. But, when he was faced with Indian raiders who attacked a party of Penn loyalists at the mouth of the Delaware River near present-day Philadelphia, he changed his plans. He returned to England and accepted a royal pardon. Upon his departure, he named the land Penn Neck (now Yorktown, Pennsylvania), after himself, and began what would become known as settlement of the “New World” and subsequent history of this region. These doctrines are based on the Jehovah's Witnesses' belief that the present state of things is the consequence of the fall of the human race into sin, and that this present state will last until the consummation of the Bible (see the following articles: The fall of man, The end of the world, Biblical prophecy and the end of the world, End of the World and The Seventh Day Adventist Church).

Hiberni (Ireland), Pictish (northern Britain) and Britons (southern Britain) tribes, all speaking Insular Celtic, inhabited the region of the Hebrides and the island of Lewis for hundreds of years before the arrival of the Europeans. The insular Celtic tribes of the Hebrides and Lewis were the most sedentary and agriculturally advanced of the Britons (though not the Gauls) and formed the first wave of colonisation in the British Isles. This in turn shaped the cultural heritage of these islands, the Scottish and Irish languages, Scots and Irish literature, and Celtic religion.

Early Insular Celtic

The Insular Celtic people (known as Iwerds or Iweardi in Scotland) formed a scattered and isolated people in remote regions of the British Isles during the Late Bronze Age, just before and coinciding with the arrival of the Romans. Sleep does not affect acquisition or recall while one is awake. Therefore, sleep has the greatest effect on memory consolidation. During sleep, the neural connections in the hippocampus grow stronger, which could explain why sleep makes the memory stronger and whether sleep makes it accessible for recall. While one could argue that one's experience of the hippocampus and the environment around it during sleeping is different than one's experience during waking, these differences seem to have only so much difference in memory strength and accessibility in the hippocampus and, in any event, could not explain such a great discrepancy in the benefits of sleeping and waking.

However, our experiments have shown that sleeping rats do improve their performance on a spatial learning task in a new environment after exposure to the same environment during sleep, unlike rats that wake up after sleeping. We argue that this improvement in spatial memory appears to be caused by the greater hippocampal synaptic density that is attained during sleep, which we hypothesize allows the brain to better store and retrieve its experiences.

The vast Seleucid Empire was, like Egypt, mostly dominated by a Greco-Macedonian political elite. The Greek population of the entire Greek world—the Hellenistic kingdoms ( _poleis Hellenicas_ ))—comprised some 80 to 200 million individuals, divided into many separate and relatively independent units ( _koheimoi_, or _poleis_ ).

During its six centuries of existence, with its powerful empire and its rich Hellenistic culture, the Seleucid Empire was one of the most advanced in the ancient world. It is considered one of the most brilliant and successful Hellenistic imperial dynasties—one that even surpassed the power of the Ptolemies in Egypt. “The roots of all our modern academic fields can be found within the pages of literature.” Literature in all its forms can be seen as an important teacher in many disciplines. As we explore, we will look at some of the uses of literature within history and other related courses.

Literature can be defined as “a genre of art and literature which derives from storytelling.” The following is a short list of some of the basic elements of literature.

Books

Book of books

A book is a collection of words, ideas, or facts and can be physical (as printed) or electronic (digitized versions). Books can be read in or out and can be used as a teaching aid for teaching the basic reader skills. A wide range of literary work is published. In addition, many works in different genres are published, which can offer a challenge for the student to relate his or her work to the work of others in a particular field.

Ideas for affirmative action came as early as the Reconstruction Era (1865-1877) in which a former slave population lacked the skills and resources necessary for the economy to survive. Blacks had little to no rights, but were left with many of the hardships of slavery along with being disallowed by law from owning property, owning their homes, and working for pay.

A new nation sought to address the issue by giving freedom to formerly enslaved people in the hope that they would use this new freedom to make their lives better. This idea was the idea of “equal opportunity” that was also the idea behind social programs like Social Security (now called Social Security Number). The NAACP led the charge in this effort to end the discrimination based on race, and through a series of federal laws, the Justice Department was able to end segregation in publicly owned institutions like banks and restaurants that were segregated based on race and even in local and state school systems that were also segregated on the basis of race

Plumage is regularly moulted; the standard plumage of a bird that has moulted after breeding is known as the "non-breeding plumage". In a few species in which plumage moult is limited to the head including the Pigeon, Turkey, and Wren, the plumage changes back and forth during the breeding and non-breeding seasons.

When birds moult, they shed feathers from the head, neck, chest, back, and outer side; if this shedding is not complete the feathers retain color. By moulting, the bird gains a fresh look, but also loses heat and, in winter-born, this is particularly important because the body is cold and feathers retain heat well. However, the feathers of birds in most groups of birds (except for the Woodpeckers, which shed their tails) do not shed the body skin entirely, losing skin only at the wings. Viking invasions began in the 9th century, followed by more permanent settlements, particularly along the east coast of Ireland, the west coast of modern day Scotland and the southwest coast of the United States. As in other times and other places, there were several phases of Viking invasion. However, since in England Viking raids stopped before the Norman conquest, and subsequent Vikings did fight only for raiding, the Norse Vikings are referred to as Viking raids, or merely as Vikings. Viking raids had an impact on the Irish, Scottish and European history until the end of the 14th century  and are considered to be a major cause of the collapse of the Roman Empire in the early Medieval period.

As cellular metabolism/energy production requires oxygen, potentially damaging (e.g., mutation causing) compounds known as free radicals can form. Most of these free radicals have highly reactive triplet (i.e., energy carrying) structures, such as superoxide anion radical O2–, hydroperoxide, singlet oxygen, and hydrogen peroxide. One-electron oxidation of molecular oxygen (O2), such as in biochemical free radical reactions, produces superoxide anion radical O2–, and two-electron oxidation of molecular oxygen produces hydrogen peroxide. This is the reason for the name “superoxide radical”, which originates from the oxidation state of the oxygen in one electron. This is also the reason why free radicals can damage cells and cause diseases (causing mutations in DNA), and such damages include cancers (e.g., lung cancer), heart disease (e.g., atherosclerosis), neurological dysfunctions, and infectious diseases.

In 1905, Lord Curzon split the large province of Bengal into a largely Hindu western half and "Eastern Bengal and Assam", a largely Muslim eastern half. (The province, which encompassed much of the Indian subcontinent, covered an area slightly larger than modern-day Turkey.)

A number of factors led to the partition of British India, which was in turn followed by the emergence of an Islamic state in the former Muslim territory of Bengal and Eastern Bengal.

One of the main issues leading up to the separation was that the British administration, which was largely controlled by Muslim Mughals, had attempted to impose a uniform set of laws on the subcontinent.

The British-controlled provinces of Bengal in particular had large Muslim populations, who had fought in the Indian wars of independence to prevent their region from being partitioned.

The phenomenalist phase of post-Humean empiricism ended by the 1940s, for by that time it had become obvious that statements about physical systems could not be true without some sort of correspondence between them and some physical, psychological or logical structure underlying mental systems. In other words, the classical empiricist conception of physicalism became untenable, due to the new fact that physical events could not have the structure of anything real. For, even the most sophisticated physical theories were not sufficiently developed to account for this structure. This fact was, then, to lead to the question of what could conceivably account for all of our knowledge or experience. This led to several, partly overlapping approaches to this challenge.

One was the attempt to discover an epistemological basis of reality, an account of what we are supposed to know, that might be independent of or more general than natural science. Perhaps this was the approach taken by the post-Humean tradition, and some of its most

The area of modern Zhejiang was outside the major sphere of influence of the Shang civilization during the second millennium BC. Instead, this area was populated by people originating from the northern regions of the Yellow River Valley region, such as Jiangxi and Fujian province.

The major sites in the region include the Haidianqiao Site, Zhangmu Village, and Dongfengdao. There is a growing body of archaeological evidence which suggests that the major civilizations of Mesopotamia and Egypt had direct contact with Zhejiang during the second millennium BC.

Predators are often another organism's prey, and likewise prey are often predators. Though blue jays prey on insects, they may in turn be preyed upon by the squirrels or chipmunks who are feeding on their insects. The larger preyed upon is a predator themselves, and we see this in the case of a wolf pack, a pack of wolves and two deer.

The smaller preyed upon is a predator of the wolf, but the bigger predator is its prey. When a deer gets close enough to a young wolf that it can nip at it, there is a fight between the deer and the mother wolf, and the mother wolf may not realize she is in danger of being eaten. But even her life, or the life of her young in the case of deer, is in great danger, for these young wolves have sharp teeth that will pierce through flesh and bone with ease and without pain and will do them no harm until the deer breaks away and runs away

The term "house music" is said to have originated from a Chicago club called The Warehouse, which existed from 1977 to 1983. Clubbers to The Warehouse were often referred to as "house music fans", while disc jockeys at other Chicago nightclubs referred to The Warehouse fans as "house-music listeners". Many of the original members of The Warehouse were DJs on other local radio stations, which further led to confusion. Many of them were also DJs at other nightclubs, such as The Cellar Bar (19781979) and The Record Room (1981). Other people working at The Warehouse became "house music producers". "House music" originally started as a dance subgenre for Chicago DJs, but was also used by pop artists such as Johnny Mathis and Madonna to describe popular dance music at the time.
