As Western Europe witnessed the formation of new kingdoms, the Eastern Roman Empire remained intact and experienced an economic revival that lasted into the early 7th century. The decline and fall of the imperial Empire of Constantinople is also reflected in the architecture, which was rebuilt during the Roman period. As a reaction to the fall of the Empire in 928, Byzantine cities built a number of walls to protect themselves with buildings, churches and fortifications.

The great period of the Roman Empire reached its pinnacle in Diocletian's time, the era of the "three golden years" of stability and power, followed by military defeats from the barbarians. This period lasted till the 5th century, and it is regarded as the Golden Age of the Roman Empire. Diocletian himself is called "Etus' Great Emperor" in the literature on the period.

Non-religious Umayyad mosaic works were mainly floor panels which decorated the palaces of the caliphs and other high-ranking officials. The decorations, often inlaid with ivory or colored enamel, used the same methods which the Greeks, particularly Callimachus and his school, used for the marble reliefs such as that depicting Oedipus at the Isthmus. The inlay and marble was very fine, and is in perfect preservation. This mosaic was found at Qal'at Al-Karkh near Ramallah, in the area of Umayyad Mosque in the late 20th century by two Palestinian Jewish antiquities explorers, Ihsan A'rav and David Kosti.

The title of "world's oldest airport" is disputed, but College Park Airport in Maryland, US, established in 1909 by Wilbur Wright, is generally recognized as having the longest runway. The first commercial air service started on November 15, 1909, when a Wright Flyer made its maiden flight from an aircraft factory in nearby Lancaster, Pennsylvania. For the next two years, other aircraft operators flew from College Park—all registered to Wright. But the Air Park's popularity waned due to a lack of infrastructure, and flight operations ceased in 1910. Wright's son, Orville Wright II, led a recovery effort over the following years, but it failed.

The name of the airport, College Park Airport (formerly Park Airport), was changed to the current version by an Air Commerce Board (ACB) order in December 1958, and it was moved to the area of the airport it currently occupies. By August 1805, Napoleon had realized that the strategic situation had changed fundamentally. Facing a potential invasion from his continental enemies, he decided to strike against Portugal before their forces could be mobilised, though if they were ready, it was far too late. A major campaign to invade Spain was necessary. An invasion force was assembled near the Pyrenees between Toulouse and Barcelona on 22 August, where Napoleon arrived with the main army, and the campaign proceeded as planned, with the invading forces sailing to Spain by sea and arriving at Burgos in late October. Although there was some doubt as to whether Britain would support the invasion, the French fleet, under the command of Admiral d’Aiguillon, crossed the Spanish Atlantic for the first time en route to the coast. It was the pub that first introduced the concept of the bar counter being used to serve the beer. Until that time beer establishments used to bring the beer through a system of trays or saucers into individual glasses, which took about half a minute per person. Each glass used to be filled by the waitress with a bar-capper, and the beer had to be emptied from there and poured into the glasses which the customers then returned. The system then required that a waitress walk around with a large, heavy pitcher or pitcher of beer to each customer, holding it in each hand, in case the customer wanted to refill his or her pint.

Another example of the old system of serving beer is that customers were only provided with a pitcher of beer rather than a glass. Beer could be transferred into the pitchers if they were empty directly from the taps. When the customers returned the glasses they were provided with were not replaced with a pitcher, but glasses.

On 29 November 1947, the United Nations General Assembly recommended the adoption and implementation of the Partition Plan for Mandatory Palestine. This UN plan specified borders for three separate countries, Jordan, Syria, and Palestine, that would be subject to negotiation by the United Arab Republic under the Partition Plan for Palestine. The UN Partition Plan for Palestine called for Arab autonomy, but not state union with Israel. However, it was widely felt among the Arab population that the United Arab Republic, a state of many separate states, was a form of independence from outside control. It seemed preferable therefore to achieve such political independence by incorporating the Syrian-occupied northern province of Syria and the West Bank into the Arab state, while preserving a Jewish majority alongside the large Arab population in what was to become Israel. These political aims were supported by many members of the ruling Arab elite, including members of al-Salam.

Valencia is a bilingual city: Valencian and Spanish are the two official languages. Spanish is official in all of Spain, whereas Valencian is spoken by about three million native people and is the most spoken language in some of the most densely populated areas of Andalusia. The two main official and unofficial languages of Valencia are Castilian and Valencian. Castilian is spoken by the majority of citizens and its influence is particularly strong in most businesses, government offices and schools, while Valencian is far and away the most spoken language in all of Andalusia.

Spanish is one of the world’s most spoken languages. It is also one of the most intelligible: even the most ignorant and poor can understand at least a few words.

Valencia is home to the Castilian-Valencian Language Council, which is run by the government and is funded with both public and private money. The Council manages the Castilian-Valencian Language

Initially, Burke did not condemn the French Revolution. In a letter of 9 August 1789, Burke wrote: "England gazing with astonishment at a revolution which has already begun, seems to anticipate some dire consequences." But Burke did not want England to become embroiled in a revolutionary war with France, and the French Revolution had, in effect, put an end to that threat. Therefore, in his second letter to the French ambassador on 15 August, Burke declared the French Revolution an act of usurpation: "It cannot be too often repeated that our conduct towards the [French] government has been dictated by a spirit of justice and moderation; that we have never attacked or threatened them, and our conduct has been dictated by the best sentiments of friendship and good-will."

Copper occurs naturally as native copper and was known to some of the oldest civilizations on record. Democratic Party candidates were consistently elected to local office, increasing the city's ties to the South and its dominant party. In 1861, Mayor Fernando Wood called on aldermen to donate three hours of time on election day to gather polling information and "wean the [troubled 1821-20] Democrats from being the mere victims of the political earthquake of 1860." In 1866, the Chicago Daily News reported that "the party which is to govern [Chicago] next spring [1868] may rely for success, upon the support of a number of prominent citizens." Chicago was officially nonpartisan on August 31, 1867.

During the Civil War, the Chicago Whigs became aligned with the Democratic Party. The following year, the Democratic Party adopted the "Chicago Platform" as its official program of a national party. Many of the non-alphanumeric characters were positioned to correspond to their shifted position on typewriters; an important subtlety is that these were not actually printed so as to have the non-alphanumeric characters printed first. When typed characters were shifted, the non-alphanumeric characters would be printed second, followed by the first row of printable characters. This arrangement would tend to render the printable character of a blank line to precede the non-alphanumeric character. If the blank line were printed before the non-alphanumeric printed character, the correct answer is not in this test, because you would read this with the shift from the first row to the second position. Therefore, only lines that are blank after the shift are correct.

The number of species invasions has been on the rise at least since the beginning of the 1900s. Species are increasingly being moved by humans (on a worldwide scale) across natural barriers, such as oceans and arctic regions, threatening global ecological systems. Although the biological invasions process is an intricate interplay of factors such as range widths and dispersal abilities, it is now clear that climate change is among the major drivers of global phenomena ([@r1]).

The impact of climate on species range or distribution can take the form of changing precipitation, temperature, and elevation distribution ranges. These changes will directly relate to the ability of an ecosystem to support species migration. The first significant work that expressed scientific theory and knowledge expressly for the laity, in the vernacular, and with the entertainment of readers in mind involved scientific and theological texts in which a text with an entertaining or poetic form was included.  A treatise on the passions, written in Latin by Peter Abelard in the first century, is one of the first of these, and was later republished as "Porcellian" or "Peter's Complaint" (1531).  Another is the tract "De Veritate Amantis" (Tractate IV.7) of a French scholastic named Rancé de la Bienheureuse (Saint-Pierre) printed in 1528. Some street trams (streetcars) used conduit third-rail current collection. The third rail was below street level. The tram picked up the current on its third rail, which allowed it to do so without a single line-gap.

If the power to a third rail is switched off, the tram is forced down the track, and the resulting back step may cause damage to components. A similar problem occurs if the third rail is used for storage instead of power supply. If current is drawn from the storage rail instead of the power supply, it is switched off and the third rail drops down causing damage or breakdown.

The trolley is a light-weight version to replace the trolleybus for the heavy traffic load over the main line.

Tensions over rising Polish nationalism and the economic effects of the Continental System led to renewed confrontation with Russia. To enforce his blockade, Napoleon launched an invasion that became known as 'La Grande Armée' ('The Great Army'). The Polish army which joined Napoleon included about 30,000 infantry and 30,000 cavalry, together with a large number of Italian mercenaries. Napoleon deployed the Prussian army in the Rhineland. Napoleon entered Poland on 29 August 1807 and made a major push against Warsaw on 4 October. The Poles, with 300 cavalry, were beaten off. In the Hesiodic Catalogue of Women, Graecus is presented as the son of Zeus and Pandora II, sister of Hellen the patriarch.  Since Graecus is mentioned once as daughter of Zeus (when she gives birth to Peleus) but is never again used as a name on the list of her family, this information may provide the first evidence of Graecus as the eponymous daughter of Zeus.  This theory is supported by the fact that he was given the epithet "of Zeus" (Graecus in Greek means "of Zeus") in place of her surname.

In biology, energy is an attribute of all biological systems from the biosphere to the smallest living organism. Within an organism it is responsible for growth and maintenance, and therefore plays a unique and significant role. For living organisms, even small energy expenditures are a fundamental element of cell life.

In the biosphere, biophysics defines the role of energy as a fundamental agent in the evolution of life by serving as a fundamental driver of all biological phenomena.

Biophysics can be used to define the impact of energy in three interrelated domains of biology: (1) the study of biophysical phenomena such as energy generation and transformation, storage and consumption, (2) the study of living systems to understand and study their mechanisms, and (3) the study of living systems to understand and influence evolution and development.

How does a living system produce and use energy? How does the living system distribute its available energy and how does it store, store and distribute its available energy?

Carolingian art was produced for a small group of figures around the court, and the monasteries and churches they supported. It was dominated by portraits, with religious statues, and the decorative arts. Carolingian art took the form of monumental sculpture, portraits, narrative sculpture, tomb statues and other religious works. It was produced during the rule of Charlemagne's son Louis the Pious who ruled in the 12th century. The art historian and art collector David Sylvester has dubbed this style 'Romanesque': it had two elements: the Carolingian tradition of painting and sculpture, and the Romanesque tradition which led to the establishment of churches and cathedrals. The sculptures and paintings from the late twelfth century were part of a unified artistic style often called 'curious'; its features were the humanized, refined, delicate style at which Michelangelo excelled. Saint-Domingue had managed to acquire a high level of political autonomy after the slave rebellion of 1791, following a similar insurrection on neighboring island of Guadeloupe in 1794. In the last years of Napoleon's administration, Saint-Domingue remained the financial and political foundation for the new United States' post-American colonial acquisitions. The works of Virgil almost from the moment of their publication revolutionized Latin poetry. The Eclogues, Georgics, and above all the Aeneid were inspired by the Latin poet who, to all outward appearance, was in no way unlike Horace, Horace's father-figure. On the other hand, Virgil belonged to a very different school of poetry, which emphasized the grandeur of classical ideas and also their dramatic, pictorial, and elegiac implications. He may have been inspired by Horace but he was certainly more than a mere imitator. His work is characterized by the most vivid imagination of his age and a very free use of the forms and instruments of the past. He has, in fact, given a free rein to the most brilliant poets of antiquity to give them the license to expand and to express the riches of the imagination on the part of the author himself. By the early 18th century, the Maratha Kingdom had transformed itself into the Maratha Empire under the rule of the Peshwas (prime ministers). The Marathas ruled India from the northern parts of the present-day Punjab to the western and southern edges of the present Bihar and Bengal states. After the 18th century, they fought several wars against the Mughals in the north and the Afghans in the south.

Their strength of rule had brought about a major impact on the Indian economy. Maratha rulers maintained a centralised system of administration, with the central authority based at Gwalior. They maintained a network of alliances stretching inwards along the north and west, connecting many states into a single whole, thus allowing a unified defence against invaders such as the Afghan Mughals. This was the most important strategy that the emperor could deploy in the Maratha struggle against the Muslims. Throughout the history of the South Slavs, the vernacular, literary, and written languages (e.g. Chakavian, Kajkavian, Travkavian, and Turešavian) formed the essential cultural and economic fabric (see below) of the culture. In the last two centuries there has been an enormous increase in the number of ethnic Bulgarophones who have adopted the official language of the new Bulgarian state and its cultural institutions. At the same time, the role of the language in shaping the national consciousness of Bulgarian Bulgarophones has diminished. This is particularly true of the young generation that grew up after their parents' migration to Bulgaria. The result of Bulgarian Bulgarophones' adaptation to the new culture and the language is that today they tend to ignore the role of the Bulgarian language in the process of national self-consciousness, language revival in the context of a broader cultural renaissance, and development of the linguistic system of the Bulgarian language.

The island of Saint Helena has a total area of 122 km2 (47 sq mi), and is composed largely of rugged terrain of volcanic origin (the Falklands, Graham Land, and South Shetland Islands) and exposed coastal plain. A short distance out of town the flat coastal plains extend inland (Somerset Island) for many miles. In addition, the island has two small offshore bays (Port Stanley and Saint Paul), the latter being used as a base for the United States Coast Guard as well as for the Australian Department of Defence.

The population consists almost entirely of the British-born and naturalized British, but has recently been colonized by a new wave of ethnic and religious minorities, notably the Portuguese, Italians, Armenians, Albanians, and Poles, as well as the Irish and Scots.

John treated the interdict as "the equivalent of a papal declaration of war". He responded by attempting to punish Innocent personally and to drive a wedge between the two popes. The Canadian football field is 150 yards (137 m) long and 65 yards (59 m) wide with end zones 20 yards (18 m) deep. In the NCAA, it is split into 15 equal-length "plays" called downs. The first play is 20 yards (18 m) from the goal line while the other 14 are 25 yards (21 m), while a "full" (also called a 15-play) is a half-mile-long line across the field, with ten 10-yard (4 m) downs.

The full is a half mile, as the length of the Canadian national football pitch is 1 mile (1.6 km) with two equal-length halves on either side. (There are two such halves in the United States, which are 0.833 mile (1.6 km) and 1 mile (1.6 km))[1]

South Korea: The event was held in Seoul, which hosted the 1988 Summer Olympics, on April 27. Intended torchbearers Choi Seung-jo and Park Sung-hyun were two of the most renowned men in South Korea, while many North Korean defectors came to take part as well. The deliberate or accidental hybridising of two or more species of closely related animals through captive breeding is a human activity which has been in existence for millennia and has been particularly significant due to the rapid development of selective breeding as a tool for genetic improvement. The selective breeding of farm animals for their meat production or meat quality has been practised ever since the ancient Egyptians domesticated animals by selective breeding, which eventually led to the large-scale mass production of livestock in the eighteenth and nineteenth century. Modern day selective breeding has focused on many agriculturally important traits such as milk lactation, meat production, disease resistance and other physiological traits such as reproduction, which are desirable in certain livestock and poultry species. Such desirable traits may be introduced at the genetic level and through the use of selective breeding techniques.
The history of the selective breeding of domestic animals is often discussed in detail in textbooks on animal breeding including "The Application of Selection to Animals" by James (1963) and "A System of Genetic Improvement"

A number of novel ideas about religion developed with the Enlightenment, including Deism and talk of atheism. Deism, according to Thomas Paine, is the religion that makes “the man of God not a God; the God of God”. Deists are atheists, denying what the Bible says about God, but not God. An early American deist, Thomas Jefferson, was the first US president to write, and sign, an “A.” (See Section 4.5) Jefferson saw religion as something a “man of God” could believe in, not something a religious person or a church leader believed in. In contrast, a modern deist is not an atheist but a non-believer.

BYU has 21 NCAA varsity teams. Nineteen of these teams played mainly in the Mountain West Conference from its inception in 1999 until the school left in 2012. In the final season after this move, eight of those teams played in the Mountain West.

BYU has more than 4,000 students, including 2,100 undergraduates. Most of its students commute to the BYU campus (also located in Provo) from Salt Lake City and Las Vegas. As a public research university, BYU has approximately 60,000 undergraduate students and 2,000 graduate students who participate in research, academic activities, and public service.

BYU students can be found participating in nearly 100 clubs. BYU has almost 90 programs for undergraduate students to participate in clubs in and out of the school, and over 50 for graduate students. It also has 16 of the 15 athletic teams competing in intercollegiate athletics, two university cheerleading squads, and three choirs.

St. John's was the capital of the British colony Newfoundland and the seat of government for many decades. Named after St. John the Divine, an ancient British saint, it is the province's second largest city after St. John's, Newfoundland, and has been named Canada's Most Active City by the Globe and Mail in 2013. The city remains an important economic hub of the province and has been a Canadian hub of commerce since the early nineteenth century. Today, St. John's is the second most cosmopolitan city of Canada (the most is Toronto), with more than 40 different nationalities and ethnicities resident. The city has been designated Cultural Capital by the Royal Canadian Geographical Society.

Switzerland lies between latitudes 45° and 48° N, and longitudes 5° and 11° E. It contains three basic topographical areas: the Alps, the Jura Range in the central plateau, and the French-speaking, or Vaudois, region.

The Celts settled here from pre-Roman times until the 1st century BC.
